document_data.caption: A guardian portrait representing [[Strahd von Zarovich]]
document_data.name: Guardian portrait
document_data.mainbody: '''Guardian portraits''' were magically animated paintings that were commonly employed as traps. They attacked by casting spells at their victims.
document_data.Description:
Those realistic portraits depicted a humanoid figure, usually someone important. The eyes of the figure gave the impression of watching and following people around but they were otherwise indistinguishable from ordinary paintings, except if inspected through magical detection.

While guardian portraits were made of both a painting and its frame, they were fused together by powerful magic and could not be taken apart.
document_data.Combat:
Guardian portraits relied on their innate [[spell|spellcasting abilities]] to attack their foes. While they could not move around, their painted figure could animate to perform [[Somatic component|somatic]] and [[verbal component|verbal]] components of the spells they cast.

Those magical [[construct]]s were known to cast spells such as ''[[counterspell]]'', ''[[crown of madness]]'', ''[[hypnotic pattern]]'' and ''[[telekinesis]]''. As with similar artificial creations, they were weak to magic-disrupting spells and effects such as ''[[dispel magic]]'' and ''[[antimagic field]]''.
